body: There are no tests associated with this pull request.  Please add tests or explain why there are not additions/modifications.
:+1:  Thanks for including tests.

before PR: reader can't process a file written by writer, only webhdfs: scheme supported
after PR: reader can process a file written by writer, hdfs: and file: schemes supported
pretty clear win.  i'm not prepared to prioritize figuring out how to run hdfs and webhdfs in a maven test harness at this time however.
There is a TwitterStreamProviderTest, however it looks like it doesn't actually enforce any assertions.
Do we have any tests in place to ensure the configurator is correctly translating the configuration?

I don't believe it's necessary to test every individual configurator - they should all be doing exactly the same thing - using TypeSafe concise rendering and Jackson to initialize a bean from a fragment of the combined json/hocon/property-file global typesafe config.

I would support adding a class to streams-config to handle this on behalf of all the module so there would just be one central place to tweak config parsing behavior in the future and adding some tests there.

IMO, the community should be organizing code to isolate difficult to test dependencies and creating issues in the tracker to do proper integration testing across external systems.  

In the case of this pull request, the getURI method should be testable without having to spin up any external dependencies on HDFS.  If we can cover those types of methods with good tests and ensure HDFS is isolated as much as possible, it would meet the minimum Ryan proposed on the list.

+1 to what Matt said, maybe creating separate JIRA issues so anybody could create the tests on the future?
Regarding the tests for the PR, why don't we use something like http://mrunit.apache.org/? That should be fairly straightforward.

Hi Steve, I also think that having a single class inside a streams-config to handle this in a centralized part would be the way to go, because having other classes doing almost the same thing makes it hard to maintain and homogenize.
Hey guys, I think this looks great! I am a big +1 to push this in, and maybe we can use this to align others? wdyt?
This is currently un-mergeable

This has been resolved by STREAMS-181

what is the decision on this?

Hi Steve,

Why don't creating separate issue per module that uses this new configuration scheme? And let PR#82 be with the one associated with updating HDFS? And it would make sense that the tests only go in the centralized configuration manager class. I am :+1: to merge this if it is done that way.
that makes sense, i will add sub-tasks for every module that has a configurator I think can be deprecated with this approach
It shouldn't - from the perspective of builds.a.o nothing has changed.  The jaxb plugin version bump could only affect xml serializers and all of the tests on those modules are still passing.
Cool, maybe I can chip in updating the other modules :)
Cool :+1:
It was just a merge from apache master into my forked repo, so it would be merge-able.  @steveblackmon  @mfranklin
oops. should be pull requests #98 and https://github.com/apache/incubator-streams/pull/99
Changed to variable to AtomicLong per feedback.

To keep my repo up to date with Apache, I create a pull request and merge in that pull request from Apache master to my forked repo master.  There was a merge conflict that I had to resolve which is why there are 2 commit hashes.

If there is a different way I should be merging Apache Master please let me know.
testRssFeedShutdownsNonPerpetual(org.apache.streams.rss.provider.RssStreamProviderTest) fails
I can't repeat the failure.  Could you please email me the failure message/stack trace.
apparently, I can't either. I have run the build with a fresh repo 5 times with no errors.
Added new tests and implementations.  Also converted most locking to Atomics
Will need to merge apache master into this branch after other pull requests are approved.
:+1:  thanks for including test coverage.
What is the reason for this change?  Do the other providers have capitalized names?
Yes: Instagram, Twitter, and RSS all have capitalized names
@mfranklin Good call. That was some lazy programming. Fixed.
About half the files changed are test files.  Lots of files had to be changed in order to support BlockingQueues.  Previously the Queue interface was all that was required.
looks good.  it builds, but loss of the LocalStreamBuilder(Queue, Map) constructor is a breaking change for every stream pipeline.
is there anyway to make this change while leaving implementations the ability to specify a specific alternative Queue class?

@steveblackmon 
So, previously the queue was able to be replaced because we were unsure of what the best implementation to use and we left it wide open and required the Queue interface.  Now it requires a blocking Queue interface.

We could open it back up to allow any BlockingQueue implementation to be put in there.  However, I do not think this is a good idea or necessary.  The user shouldn't have a need to define the message passing from each StreamsOperation.  I believe the user should only have the option to decide how many datums are allowed to be on each queue.  This allows us to make changes to the local stream builder, swap the queue for other message passing systems, etc.,  without introducing breaking changes in the future.  

This is a breaking change.  Which does need to be communicated through the email list serve before this gets merged in (good catch on that).  However, I think it is a needed breaking change.

tentative +1, provided there are no other objections.  i'm comfortable delegating framework queueing to the runtime.

i've got a branch of w2ogroup/streams-examples with alternative constructors where everything builds, which will merge shortly after this does.
Changed method due to feedback.
Could you add some tests for these new processors?
tests added
Give me some time to review the changes as it is very large.  But it is under review.

cuts down on duplicated code.  we don't have a great pattern for resolving a tuple from several incomplete sources each contributing a field or two where the precedence may differ by use case.  i suspect we will need one.
Hey guys, quick question. Is there any special reason why the usage of Cloudera's Pig over Apache's? Shouldn't we choose Apache version over a specific vendor?
Since this @After block is used in every one of these tests, would it make sense to have these tests extend a test superclass that has that implemented?

@robdouglas 
Yes, but some of the tests extend RandomizedTest, and since Java does not allow multiple inheritance I chose to go with just added it to every test.  We could look at at having a class that extends RandomizedTests first, but I didn't want to force all tests to extend RandomizedTests at the moment.  I would want to do some more testing before forcing that.
Sounds good :+1:
Not sure why it has so many commit hashes.  Only one from me is the last one.
So this basically allows you to optional load new percolate rules and remove them afterwords, instead of the delete->load->delete process being automatic?

All tags defined in the config will be loaded no matter - this patch makes deletion before and after optional.

> On Oct 31, 2014, at 3:36 PM, Ryan Ebanks notifications@github.com wrote:

the event detection changes anticipate a use case where a stream doesn't know the type OR channel of an inbound event and needs streams to find the best available serializer on the classpath to get an Activity
merged along with STREAMS-168
merged along with STREAMS-168
looks good.  maybe beyond the scope of this PR, but does this new monitoring approach provide a mechanism to observe throughput queue details on a periodic basis via slf4j logs?

At the moment, it does not. However, the next step with this would be to actually "broadcast" these monitoring messages/objects to predetermined location so that they could be aggregated. It should be a pretty straightforward extension to persist these messages via slf4j logs as well.
+1, provided we add a story to re-enable inspection from watching console / tailing log files via slf4j.
